description:
Astrovirus VA1 is a member of the Astroviridae family, a group of small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. It was first identified in 2008 from fecal samples of a child with gastroenteritis in Virginia, United States.

Astrovirus VA1 is classified within the Mamastrovirus genus, which includes astroviruses that primarily infect mammals. The viral genome is approximately 6.8 to 7.3 kilobases in length and encodes three open reading frames (ORFs) that produce the viral structural and non-structural proteins.

Astrovirus VA1 is primarily associated with acute gastroenteritis in humans, particularly in young children. It can cause symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. The virus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, and it can be detected in stool samples using molecular techniques like reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR).

Ongoing research aims to better understand the epidemiology, clinical significance, and potential public health impact of Astrovirus VA1 infections, as well as to develop effective diagnostic tools and potential therapeutic interventions.
